awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Innovative Two-Phase Cooling with Micro Closed Loop Pulsating Heat Pipes for High Power Density Electronics
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is the development of improved thermal cooling solutions for mobile devices.  Cooling solutions today are often unable to meet the demands of 5G/6G telecommunications with thermal heating rates up to 10 times that of 4G technologies. Even current high performance 5G mobile phones have greatly increasing thermal loads, which, in turn, increase the external touch temperature of the smart phone and often trigger the phone to slow down its speed. The proposed technology may result in improved cooling for increased performance without limitations of performance throttling.  Enhancing thermal cooling capabilities of cutting edge mobile devices may help enable widespread adoption of 5G/6G telecommunications, virtual and augmented reality, artificial intelligence, self-driving cars, and big data applications.

This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project develops a new passive micro-two-phase cooling based on pulsating heat pipes, which consist of a loop of microchannels in a flat plate in which oscillations of the coolant in the serpentine are generated by vapor bubbles to pump liquid and vapor to transport higher heat loads.  The design harnesses complex self-induced pulsations to better perform the work of transferring larger quantities of heat by enhancing the pulsating heat pipe's fluid motion with localized obstructions to create distributed bubble nucleation points. The same obstructions will be used to improve the micro-thermal heat transfer processes. The project introduces microfluidics to pulsating heat pipes.  The research objectives of the proposed project are to demonstrate substantial improvements in thermal performance compared to competing cooling technology (vapor chambers) at the same thin form factors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The ever-growing performance of high-density mobile computing and power micro-electronics is severely impacted by the limited availability of efficient cooling solutions that save energy and cost and are environmentally friendly and compact/light weight.  A new innovative two-phase cooling approach with micro Closed Loop Pulsating Heat Pipes (CLPHP) was developed by the Global Cooling Technology Group LLC (GCTG) that improves electronics performance while reducing both its electrical energy consumption and environmental impact by patent-pending microchannel enhancement features. To our knowledge no one has successfully commercialized micro CLPHPs with internal lthermal enhancements at dimensions compatible with mobile devices, i.e., with thickness less than 1 mm. As opposed to conventional heat pipes, a CLPHP (Figure 1) consists of a closed loop of serpentine microchannels in a flat plate (no wicking structure), that relies on instabilities generated by vapor bubbles forming, growing, flowing and condensing to move fluid and heat efficiently, in fact more efficiently and at higher rates than heat pipes and vapor chambers (essentially two-dimensional heat pipes that still require wicking structures). GCTG patent-pending CLPHP prototypes were designed and manufactured out of ceramic for enhanced visualization and to enable further microchannel design enhancements for metallic applications. Experiments performed at Arizona State University demonstrated superior performance relative to a state-of-the-art competing cooling technology (vapor chamber) and highly conductive copper and aluminum plates, for both vertical and horizontal orientations. Exceeding the Phase I cooling target by 27% was enabled by microscale enhancements to the internal channels which increased surface area and improved the evaporation and condensation processes. These fundamental advances were due in part to the application of advanced two-phase flow analysis and microscale manufacturing approaches developed by GCTG. The mobile electronics industry is very sensitive to size (volume) and weight: for both of these the CLPHP greatly outperformed the vapor chamber by 250 - 480%. The documented improvements in cooling require less volume since GCTG CLPHPs improve the heat spreading in a very compact/thin form factor and do not require fans or active pumping.   Environmental impact is minimized by saving energy and through the use of an environmentally friendly refrigerant as the working fluid.  The GCTG CLPHPs work well irrespective of orientation, a great benefit for mobile/portable devices that are highly sensitive to orientation.  

The broader impacts of the GCTG technology include helping the US de-carbonizing efforts through energy consumption reduction (cleanest, least intrusive new alternative energy is that which is never consumed!). Furthermore, GCTG will create new US manufacturing jobs and will play a key role in the US winning the 5G/6G Telecoms and Artificial Intelligence (AI) races with worldwide competitors.


Last Modified: 06/22/2023
Modified by: Victor A Chiriac
